forms.document_type: ROI authorization form (current 2025 Spanish fillable version)

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patients download a generic system-wide HIPAA authorization form, select 'Personal' as the purpose, fill the fillable PDF, print and wet-ink sign it, then fax or mail it to HIM.

red_flags: Wet-ink signature mandate prevents fully electronic submission
No distinction between patient access fees and third-party release fees
No reference to HIPAA Right of Access (§ 164.524)
bright_spots: Bilingual fillable PDF (English and Spanish) with 65 interactive fields
MyChart patient portal available as a fully digital alternative for post-2018 records
Numbered section-instruction pairing reduces form completion confusion
Active form maintenance visible across three revision generations (2016, 2022, 2025)

findability.rationale: Level 4: Easy to find with basic navigation — the ROI page is clearly linked under the Patients section and the first web search immediately surfaced direct PDF links.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: Usable digitally with workarounds — the form has 65 fillable fields for on-screen completion, but the wet-ink signature requirement forces printing, and submission is via fax or mail.

content_design.rationale: Level 4: Well-organized with minor clarity issues — numbered sections map to instructions, plain-language parentheticals aid understanding, but the dual From/To sections have identical confusing instructions.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the process but it wasn't designed for them — the generic authorization form serves all release purposes and patients must select 'Personal' and navigate the From/To structure without Right of Access guidance.

compliance.rationale: Level 3: Some requirements that may go beyond what the law requires — the wet-ink signature mandate is not legally required for patient access requests, and fee language is vague without distinguishing patient access from third-party release fee limits.

overall.summary: St. Charles Redmond provides a findable, well-constructed fillable form in two languages, but funnels patients through a generic authorization process with a wet-ink signature barrier and no dedicated patient access pathway.
